p.s: Gatsby is really nervous about the visit from Daisy and firstly reveals his insecurities in front of Nick.
But in the excerpt is a change of Gatsby's character and he seems truly happy.
Right in the beginning of the excerpt the reader gets an impression how nervous Gatsby is, because of the meeting with Daisy.
The author makes clear how hard it is for Gatsby to meet Daisy, because he is so scared.
He underlines this with the comparison with his hands plunged like weights (p. 84, l. 15).
Gatsby even tries to escape the situation and changes rooms to not see Daisy (p. 84, l. 18f.).
This shows how much Daisy means to him and how important it is for him, what Daisy thinks about him.
But eventhougheven though he is so nervous, he acts calm and disintresseddisinterested in front of Daisy (p. 84, l. 28).
This reveals his character because it shows that Gatsby creates a certain picture of himself in front of other people.
This aspect combines the character of Gatsby in the previous chapters, where he is described at his own parties.
It shows that he is not throwing the parties to enjoy an evening with his friends, but to show the people that he is able to throw parties like that and to show off his house and wealth.
This also creates a picture of him, as a powerfullpowerful and rich man.
Gatsby also enjoys the feeling of power in this excerpt.
He seems less nervous when he stared down at Daisy (p. 84, l. 30f.).
This shows how insecure he really is, because he needs the power over other people to feel confident.
His insecurity is also revealed when Nick wants to leave the room and Gatsby and Daisy alone.
Gatsby follows him and opens up to Nick, how nervous and scared he is.
His desperation is underlined with the repeat of the word terrible mistake (p. 86, l. 1f.).
The narrator points out how silly Gatsby acts, because he is really nervous but creates this disintresseddisinterested picture in front of Daisy.
He compares him with a little boy (p. 86, l. 8) and tells him that he is also acting rude (p. 86, l. 9).
In this excerpt Gatsby is not able to overplay his insecurities with his power of being a rich man and showing off his money.
In previous chapters he does not seem so nervous and insecure because he mostly shows the other people how wealthy he is, what makes him feel self-confident.

In this excerpt the author shows Gatsby in a situation, where he is not surrounded by things that make him look rich and give him power, in order to reveal his insecurities and show how materialistic he really is.
The absurdity of the situation is underlined when Nick leaves the house and goes in the garden.
From there he can see Gatsby's enormous house (p. 86, l. 19) and all the people that work for him.
This picture of a powerfullpowerful and rich man, who owns this is put in contrast to his behavior before and shows that this is just a shell.
When Nick comes back in the house the atmosphere has completely changed.
Every verstige of embarassmentembarrassment was gone(p. 87, l. 10f.).
This change is also provoked by the change of weather It's stopped raining (p. 87, l. 18).
Rain conveys this feeling of an uncomfortable situation and with the ending of the rain the situation also gets more comfortable and changes in a positive way.
The contrast between rain and sunshine (p. 87, l. 20) underlines the change of the situation.
This positive change is also portrayed in Gatsby.
He literally glowed(p. 87, l. 14).
The use of the comparison like an estatic patron of recurrent light (p. 87, l. 21) contributes to this positive picture of Gatsby in this moment.
The change of Gatsby's character shows how much Daisy means to him and how her presence influences Gatsby in a positive way.
In conclusion the scene reveals a lot about Gatsby's character.
He seems really insecure and tries to overplay that by creating the picture of being a powerfullpowerful and rich man.
This shell is taken down by Daisy and Gatsby seems to really enjoy a moment for the first time in the novel.
